metadata.usage_notes: Production-validated entries prioritized. Genre tags enable Tier 2 conditional loading for fantasy/historical novels.

common_compounds.usage: Describing heroines, scenery. Most common compound. Translate as single word, not character-by-character.

kanji_entries.translation_notes: Often appears in 綺麗{きれい}. High RTAS context (4.5+) requires careful tone. Furigana indicates single-word reading.

kanji_entries.kun_reading: うるわ.しい, うら.らか

common_compounds.usage: Most common usage - part of 綺麗

kanji_entries.translation_notes: Han-Viet 'lệ' too formal for romcom. Use 'xinh đẹp', 'rạng rỡ' depending on context. Distinguish compound vs standalone usage.

common_compounds.vn_translation: đôi mắt, ánh mắt, con ngươi
common_compounds.usage: Emotional descriptions - eyes glistening, intense gaze

kanji_entries.translation_notes: 瞳 (hitomi) vs 目 (me) - 瞳 more poetic/emotional, emphasizes pupil/inner eye. Han-Viet 'đồng tử' too clinical. Use 'đôi mắt', 'ánh mắt' for RTAS 4.0+ scenes.

common_compounds.usage: Describing character gazes in emotional scenes

kanji_entries.translation_notes: 眼差し (manazashi) vs 視線 (shisen) - manazashi more poetic, emphasizes emotion. Han-Viet 'nhãn' too formal. Often modified: 真剣な眼差し (serious gaze).

common_compounds.vn_translation: hôn thê, vợ chồng tương lai

kanji_entries.translation_notes: 許嫁 (iinazuke) is plot keyword for arranged marriage trope. Distinguish from 婚約者 (fiancé via mutual engagement). Core term for romcom subgenre.

kanji_entries.on_reading: セイ, ショウ, シン
kanji_entries.kun_reading: きよ.い, きよ.まる, きよ.める

common_compounds.vn_translation: thanh tao, trong sáng, tinh khôi

kanji_entries.translation_notes: 清楚 (seiso) is character archetype keyword. Often contrasted with 色気 (sexiness). Use 'thanh tao', 'trong sáng', 'tinh khôi' for variety.

common_compounds.vn_translation: quyến rũ, mê hoặc, hấp dẫn
common_compounds.usage: Describing seductive expressions/behavior in romantic tension

kanji_entries.translation_notes: 蠱惑 (kowaku) is literary term. Han-Viet 'cổ hoặc' archaic. Use 'quyến rũ', 'mê hoặc' for RTAS 4.5+ scenes. Must convey allure without vulgarity.

kanji_entries.kun_reading: うずくま.る, つくば.う

common_compounds.vn_translation: co ro, thu mình, cúi rạp

kanji_entries.translation_notes: 蹲る (uzukumaru) conveys vulnerability. Han-Viet 'tồn' rare. Use 'co ro', 'thu mình' to preserve emotional tone. Common in bullying/trauma flashbacks.
諫める (isameru) vs 戒める (imashimeru) - 諫 = respectful remonstration, 戒 = strict warning. Distinguish tone. Use 'khuyên bảo', 'nhắc nhở' for playful context.
お揃い (osoroi) implies pride in matching with loved one. Han-Viet 'toàn' not intuitive. Use 'giống nhau', 'cùng màu' with emotional undertone.

common_compounds.vn_translation: anh dũng, kiên định, oai phong

kanji_entries.translation_notes: Common in character names (female). 凛々しい for male dignity, 凛とした for female composure. Han-Viet 'lẫm' rare.

common_compounds.vn_translation: phù du, thoáng qua, mỏng manh

kanji_entries.translation_notes: Highly poetic. Use 'phù du', 'thoáng qua', 'mỏng manh' for wistful tone. Common in tragic romance or philosophical reflection.

common_compounds.vn_translation: khát khao, mơ ước, ngưỡng mộ

kanji_entries.translation_notes: Common in school LN. 憧れる (akogareru) = yearn for, admire. Use 'khát khao', 'ngưỡng mộ' for romantic admiration context.
頬 (hoo) for cheek. Han-Viet 'giáp' not common. Use 'má' (Vietnamese). Common in RTAS 4.0+ intimate scenes.

common_compounds.usage: My humble self (female POV in feudal settings)

kanji_entries.translation_notes: Archaic first-person pronoun (feminine). Common in historical/fantasy LN with feudal settings. Han-Viet 'thiếp' directly maps.
Core term for historical/fantasy LN. Often romanized 'samurai' in Vietnamese. Han-Viet 'thị' less common than loan word.

common_compounds.usage: Long sword worn slung from belt

kanji_entries.translation_notes: 刀 (katana) vs 剣 (tsurugi) - 刀 = curved blade (katana), 剣 = straight blade. Distinguish in martial contexts. Han-Viet 'đao' maps well.
剣 (tsurugi/ken) = straight blade. Differentiate from 刀 (curved katana). Common in fantasy RPG settings. Han-Viet 'kiếm' perfect match.
Ultra-rare. Archery equipment in historical battles. No Han-Viet mapping. Translate as 'ống đựng tên', 'hộp tên'.
Common in historical/fantasy female character descriptions. Han-Viet 'trâm' maps well. Often ornamental, symbolic of status.
Ultra-rare. Horse equipment in feudal contexts. No Han-Viet. Translate descriptively as 'dây trâm ngực ngựa'.
Rare. Horse tack in historical military contexts. No Han-Viet. Use 'dây cương', 'hàm thiếc'.
Ultra-rare. Mounted archery equipment. No Han-Viet. Translate descriptively.
Rare archery equipment. No Han-Viet. Use 'nhẫn bắn cung', 'bọc ngón tay'.
Chinese mythical creature. Rare in LN. No Han-Viet. Romanize 'xiezhi' or translate descriptively.

common_compounds.usage: Large mythical ape from Chinese legend

kanji_entries.translation_notes: Rare mythical creature. No Han-Viet. Translate descriptively as 'khỉ khổng lồ thần thoại'.
Chinese folklore creature. Use 'yêu tinh núi', 'ma quỷ núi'. No Han-Viet.
Rare marine creature. No Han-Viet. Use 'cua móng ngựa'.
Archaic kanji for crocodile (modern: 鰐). Use 'cá sấu'. No Han-Viet.

common_compounds.usage: Japanese chimera with monkey head, tiger body

kanji_entries.translation_notes: Famous Japanese yokai. Romanize 'nue' or translate as 'quái vật Nhật Bản'. No Han-Viet.
Rare variant for phoenix. Use 'phượng hoàng'. No Han-Viet.
Chinese mythical bird symbolizing conjugal love. Use 'chim uyên ương thần thoại'. No Han-Viet.
Medical/anatomical term. Rare in LN. No Han-Viet. Use 'xương đùi', 'ổ khớp hông'.
Anatomical term. Rare in LN except medical/injury scenes. No Han-Viet. Use 'xương bả vai'.
Medical term. Very rare in LN. No Han-Viet. Use 'xương bánh chè'.
Archaic for skull (modern: 頭蓋骨). Rare in LN except horror/dark fantasy. No Han-Viet. Use 'hộp sọ'.
Archaic punishment term. Very rare. No Han-Viet. Translate as 'hình phạt cạo đầu'.
Archaic negative descriptor. Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'đần độn', 'ngây thơ'.
Archaic descriptor for barbaric characters. No Han-Viet. Use 'hung dữ', 'man rợ'.
Archaic term for beauty/adornment. Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'trang điểm đẹp', 'nhan sắc'.
Archaic clothing. Rare except historical/xianxia fantasy. No Han-Viet. Use 'áo choàng lông'.
Very rare. Archaic footwear term. No Han-Viet. Use 'dép', 'giày trẻ em'.
Ultra-rare archaic clothing. No Han-Viet. Translate descriptively.
Archaic term for wig. Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'tóc giả'.
Archaic hairstyle term. Very rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'tóc xõa'.
Mourning ritual hairstyle. Ultra-rare. No Han-Viet. Translate descriptively.
Archaic hairstyle verb. Very rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'búi tóc', 'cột tóc'.
Animal feature. Common in fantasy with horses/lions. No Han-Viet. Use 'bờm'.
Literary euphemism for death. Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'qua đời', 'băng hà'.
Tragic death term. Very rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'chết đói'.
Archaic hunting method. Rare. No Han-Viet. Translate descriptively.
Seasonal hunting term. Very rare. No Han-Viet. Translate descriptively.
Archaic verb for washing face. Very rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'rửa mặt'.
Poetic verb for soaring. Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'bay vút', 'bay cao'.
Archaic food term. Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'cá khô'.
Variant for dried fish. Very rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'cá khô'.
Dried seafood. Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'mực khô'.
Archaic cooking vessel. Rare except fantasy kitchens. No Han-Viet. Use 'nồi gang', 'vạc lớn'.
Culinary term. Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'trứng cá'.
Literary bird metaphor for colleagues. Ultra-rare. No Han-Viet. Translate metaphorically.
Rare bird species. Ultra-rare in LN. No Han-Viet. Translate descriptively.
Poetic variant for swallow (modern: 燕). Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'chim yến'.
Rare bird, also symbol of 5th grade official. Historical contexts. No Han-Viet.
Archaic for chick (modern: 雛). Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'gà con', 'chim non'.
Variant for quiver. Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'túi đựng tên', 'bao tên'.
Horse equipment. Very rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'tấm lót yên ngựa'.
Archaic for reins (modern: 手綱). Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'dây cương'.
Archaic musical instrument. Very rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'trống cầm tay'.
Traditional Japanese/Chinese instrument. Rare. No Han-Viet. Romanize 'sho' or use 'sáo sheng'.

kanji_entries.kun_reading: たたか.う, あらそ.う
kanji_entries.translation_notes: Archaic variant of 闘 (fight). Rare. Han-Viet 'đấu' maps. Use 'chiến đấu', 'đấu tranh'.

kanji_entries.kun_reading: たたか.う, あらそ.う
kanji_entries.translation_notes: Another archaic variant of 闘. Very rare. Han-Viet 'đấu' maps. Use 'thi đấu', 'tranh đấu'.

usage_guidelines.tier_1_injection: Always inject top 14 production-validated entries (綺, 麗, 瞳, 眼, 許, 清, 蠱, 蹲, 諫, 揃, 凛, 儚, 憧, 頬) for all VN translations.
usage_guidelines.tier_2_conditional: Load archaic/fantasy entries (妾, 侍, 刀, 剣, etc.) based on genre metadata: historical, fantasy, martial_arts, xianxia.
usage_guidelines.tier_3_on_demand: Ultra-rare entries (anatomical, mythical, archaic hairstyles) loaded only if kanji detected in source text.
usage_guidelines.external_service: Week 3 implementation - SQLite kanji service for edge cases with no Han-Viet mapping.

notes: Production audit (0d29, 16a0) validated 10 high-frequency kanji in romcom genre.
Task 1.4 extraction provided 98 additional entries for fantasy/historical coverage.
Han-Viet 'N/A' entries require external kanji service (Week 3).
Priority tags: TOP (綺), HIGH (麗, 瞳, 眼, 許, 蠱), MEDIUM (others), LOW (ultra-rare).
